Eternal Spirit!  mightiest though unknown,</br>Yet seen and felt o'er all the breathing earth;</br>From the dark thunder of thy cloudy throne,</br>To the young zephyr in its hour of birth!</br>Thou smil'st, — the universe is full of mirth,</br>And nature wantons in those moments bright:</br>Thou frown'st, — and darkness walks sublimely forth:</br>Thou spread'st abroad thy wings, and solemn night</br>Swathes round a million suns, that trembling hide their light!

Unsearchable — unalterable thy ways!</br>The immortal soul but sees of thee a part:</br>No one can tell thy awful length of days,</br>Nor dream of thy departure! — no:  thou wert</br>Before the worlds were fashion'd, and thou art</br>The same to-day as yesterday; on thee,</br>Time and decay can leave no stain; thy heart</br>Departs not with the pigmy worlds we see,</br>They drop in dust away — but thou remainest free!

Bestriding space! — in darkness thou dost stand</br>In solitary might, holding the spheres</br>Within the hollow of thy dreadful hand;</br>The lightning gems thine awful brow, nor sears:</br>Eternity rolls round thee, but his years</br>Can leave no blight upon thy glorious form,</br>The blast that through infinitude careers</br>The comets spring, launch'd from thy mighty arm,</br>Whilst thou, in glory walks calm o'er the thunder storm!

Unchanged for ever thou hast been, and still</br>Unsullied — and unchanged will brightly be;</br>The million, million worlds, but only fill</br>A little speck of thy immensity!</br>Oh!  still this erring world is loved by thee—</br>Ancient of Days, thy wings are stretch'd as bright</br>As when thy spirit, on Time's jubilee,</br>Dovelike descended from thy holy height,</br>And said to light — Arise!  and there was life and light.</br>
